subtitle: Place your advance order now on Amazon for the very first volume of the New Thinking
Allowed Dialogue series, Is There Life After Death?
Publication date is June 1st.
Thinking Allowed, conversations on the leading
edge of knowledge and discovery with psychologist
Jeffrey Mishlove.
Hello and welcome.
I'm Jeffrey Mishlove.
Today we'll be talking about psychedelics and the soul.
My guest is Rachel Harris.
She has been a psychotherapist for more than
four decades, starting out in the 1960s as
a staff member at the Esalen Institute.
She is author of Listening to Ayahuasca, New
Hope for Depression, Addiction, PTSD and Anxiety.
Her newest book, which we'll be talking about,
is Swimming in the Sacred, Wisdom from the
Psychedelic Underground.
Rachel lives in the state of Maine on a remote island.
Now, I'll switch over to the internet video.
Welcome Rachel.
It's a real pleasure to be with you.
It's been a few years.
Thank you so much.
I'm thrilled to be here.
Your new book is profound in my mind.
The reason I say that, and I happen to know for a fact that many other reviewers have
said as much as well, is because you've discovered
and reported on a hidden treasure, really.
Women who have been involved in the psychedelic
underground, as you call it, for many, many
decades and who have been serving, I think,
as spiritual guides for people, at great risk
to themselves and totally immersing themselves
in the underground culture of psychedelics.
What your book points out is that these people
have, over many decades, acquired a certain
wisdom that completely transcends all of the new
work that we talk about a lot in the so-called
psychedelic renaissance.
The new crop of therapists and researchers
don't have half of the experience that these
women have.
That's right.
We don't want to lose their voices and we're
at risk because they are continuing to work
underground so they're not giving talks at the conferences.
The interesting thing, Rachel, is that you yourself almost qualify to be a member of
this group.
You've been around pretty much as long as they've been.
You've been exposed to psychedelics.
You're familiar with all the literature, but
you're very clear that you would not consider
yourself such a person.
Oh, no.
I'm very clear because basically I'm afraid of everything.
They are not.
They are afraid of nothing.
There's no way I qualified.
I knew many of the people they trained with in the 60s.
I was around.
One woman, when I went to meet her, we recognized each other.
We had been around in the same circles, but no, I never really qualified.
These women were just courageous to take any
and all of the medicines at all the different
levels of dosages.
I was always, and I continue to be, very careful and cautious with my own journeys.
But does such bravery really recommend itself
as someone you would want to have guiding
you on a trip?
Well, you know, I really do want someone who
knows the territory very well, absolutely.
Because I mean, think about it.
They have very few clues to travel with you.
So you know, I did a journey with one of the
women and I'm under a blanket with earphones
and eye shades.
What cues can she pick up to know what's happening inside me?
Because I'm not talking, I'm busy.
And so she, because of her experience, is able to intuit into my journey almost as if
she's there with me.
And of course she was physically with me, but I always felt her presence.
And that was so different from the trips really
that I took in the 60s, which were in nature
and my intention was spiritual.
I never did the big concert music, you know, rock music trips.
I never did that.
But even in nature, it's not the same as having someone right there for you.
And then toward the end of that journey,
she did this very sophisticated clearing and
cleansing with energy work that she did with
some shamanic tools and fans and feathers
and incense, you know, different smells.
It was just extraordinary.
And that probably went on for an hour.
She really cleared things out.
So at the end of the journey, I came back in
a different space, I mean, really different.
And that, you know, people certainly have wonderful experiences in nature.
And it's different with a guide, with somebody sitting right there.
You write about one instance in which a guide
explained to you that they were working with
a client.
I guess that was the word they used.
And during the trip, the client relived an experience.
I think it was a father or a grandfather had had while they were drowning.
And I can imagine that must be a very difficult
situation if you're a guide and the person
you're with is having the experience of drowning.
Right.
Yes.
These women have so much experience working with people.
I mean, when I talk about how experienced they are, they spent years working on their
own healing before they began to sit with other people.
And by years, I mean five, six years.
And the truth is they continue to work on their own healing.
The use of entheogens covers a whole lifetime.
So they worked on themselves.
And then with supervision, with guidance,
with a mentor, they began to work with other
people.
So they've experienced a lot of different situations.
I mean, one woman told me a story of she realized
at a certain point in a journey she was sitting
with someone, they had to go to the ER.
And that's a big decision because you walk
into the emergency room and you're confessing
to an illegal activity.
And she said, we were just lucky that the
doctor on call was simpatico and he protected
her and treated the client.
That took a lot of courage and she had to have real confidence in her own experience
to make that judgment call, to know when to go get help.
I can imagine that for these people working
outside of the legal system without any medical
insurance to cover them if anything should go
wrong and with all kinds of legal exposures.
I think in one instance you described a guide
who had been sued by one of their clients
and no certification of any sort.
Right.
Right.
And, of course, that was for inappropriate behavior on the guide's part.
So there are cases of that that the community
and the profession has to begin to deal with
because there is no professional body like
there is the American Psychological Association
where you can lose your license if the person is not licensed to begin with.
How can they be managed?
And so this is being explored now.
It's an important discussion to have right now.
I know that the state of Oregon has already
licensed a couple of people to serve as guides
for psilocybin trips.
The state of Colorado is doing the same thing right now.
To the best of my knowledge, those licensing
or certification requirements are very minimal.
People with no particular educational qualifications
can take a test and a six-week course or a
12-week course and go into business or will be able to soon, I think, in the states of
Colorado and Oregon.
Yes.
The requirement is a high school diploma.
So I don't know what to say about this.
I mean, you know, we're all just sort of hoping for the best.
But people with experience are very concerned about the potential risks here.
An online course, whether it's six weeks or even some of the courses are a year long,
that doesn't replace the years of experience of working on yourself.
I mean, one of the women I interviewed, when
I told her, look, licensed therapists, there's
no requirement for them to have their own therapy.
She just could not believe it.
She didn't know that.
And she just could not believe therapists
could open up a practice and do therapy with
people without having done their own work.
And that has really been one of the rules for the underground women.
And yes, they are outside of the normal structures.
And they also have colleagues, they can call
each other, and they have physicians they
work with, and they have licensed therapists they refer to.
So they've been in practice a long time, and
they have built up a professional network
that provides extra options for the client and for them.
And they're very careful about the medical intake that they do.
And that's one of the key warnings I tell people.
And I say, you know, if you're going to do a
ceremony and nobody's taken a really careful
medical history, don't go.
So that's how important that medical history is.
A good point.
I mean, you're in a room with people who are also using some sort of a very powerful
entheogen, and you may not know what will emerge in the other people who you're with.
Yes, there's that as well.
Yeah.
Well, you've interviewed 15 people intensively
for your book, and even above and beyond that
you refer to many, many other people who are sort of in the periphery of the sort of
work you're doing.
Yes.
Let's talk a little bit about the, what can I call it, the training.
That's really not the right word.
I know you point out it's not a training, but
they go through a process, and apprenticeship
I think is the word you use.
Yes, that's the word I use.
And everybody is different.
I mean, one woman did a traditional training with the Shapipo shaman.
So she spent a good bit of time in Peru.
That's a certain kind of training.
And one of the stories she told me, and I think she's one of the few who really did
this kind of training.
She said after five years, maybe six, the shaman said to her, you're ready to sing,
which is the mechanism of the healing in the Shapipo ceremony.
She said, no, I'm not ready.
She waited a whole other year before she felt ready.
And during that year, she sat at the shaman's elbow.
This is the phrase for an apprenticeship,
that you are right at their elbow, right next
to them.
And he would sing, and she would sing a nanosecond after him.
So she was like right behind him, so to speak.
And then together with him, she could say,
well, did you see this in the person's body?
And what happened when you did that?
And to check out her shamanic perceptions as she was learning.
And so she waited that whole extra year.
We don't hear that from people these days.
People come up to me at conferences and say,
Grandmother Ayahuasca told me I should be
leading ceremonies, and I'm trying to control myself.
And I say, well, how many ceremonies have you done?
And they say five.
And I think, well, you know, in six more years, maybe.
So it's a whole different perspective on what it takes to do this work.
Which also means that there are certain risks
involved, to be honest, for anybody who chooses
to move in this direction.
Whether you're working with a professional
psychotherapist, or a shaman, or an apprentice
of one or the other, there are lots of unknowns.
Yes, yes, there are many unknowns, and things cannot be controlled.
There has to be a willingness to go with what's happening.
And the phrase, and I remember this phrase from the 60s, you know, when I was around
many of these same communities and situations,
I was living at Esalen in the late 60s.
The phrase was, trust the process.
And that is a very accurate phrase, and it's not so easy to do.
Especially if the process is that you're freaking out.
Yes, exactly.
Which, you know, is the sort of thing that I'd be very concerned about.
But they have, after their years of their own
work, and their training, and their experience,
their working with people, even more experienced than they were.
They worked with elders in the 60s.
They sort of have an intuition that they trust that's deep in their bones.
And I don't have that kind of certainty.
I'm always filled with questions and doubts.
That's my nature.
But they have a real kind of somatic embodied
certainty that they will have the intuition,
they will have the help from spirit guides, from their ancestors.
They have help from unseen sources that, again, this is different for me.
I mean, I'm much more open to this now, but
it's, you know, I don't have the same confidence
they have.
They're deeply, deeply in their bones.
They trust the process, and they know they'll
have help, and they know the territory.
This is a different kind of person.
Now, I'm a little surprised to hear you say that about yourself, Rachel, because we've
done three earlier interviews on ayahuasca, and in one interview, which we're going to
re-release soon, incidentally, on grandmother
ayahuasca, as I recall, you described that
you felt you were having a personal relationship
with this being, this ayahuasca being that
you called grandmother ayahuasca, and then
later on, you write in your book, well, you're
not so sure it's real.
Well, this is my own craziness, and this is why I was never one of these guides.
Yes, I absolutely had and have that relationship.
And you know, that relationship helped me to write that book, and that relationship
did not help me write this book, because this book is about all the medicines.
And it's not really just, it didn't come out
of that relationship with that plant teacher.
So yes, I'm absolutely certain about my experience,
and I don't, I still have doubts and questions.
It's just part of my nature to question.
I kind of think that's healthy.
I'm pretty much the same way I attribute it
to, if you want to get esoteric, to the fact
that I have Libra as my rising sign, so I'm always weighing and balancing alternatives
and rarely settling on just one.
But one of the very important aspects of your
new book is that you chose to limit, for the
most part, all of the people you're writing
about are female, and I think that's crucial.
That's interesting.
You know, I've been afraid to talk about that
too much, because I don't want to get, you
know, I don't want to get...
Boxed in.
Yes, thank you.
That's a nice way to put it.
Some of it was I just, you know, I'm in my mid-70s, I've listened to men all my life,
and it's like enough already.
And I, but to be more subtle about it is I
thought that women have a special relationship
with the medicines.
I felt they have a more personal relationship
with the spirit of the plants, with different
types of medicines, with their ancestors and healing guides.
I just felt they had a sensitivity to this
other world that I was really wanting to explore
and highlight.
I think that's part of the gift.
It's not to say that the men don't have that,
but it's held differently in the male energy.
And I, you know, some of it is that one of
the conferences, and this was, I think, around
2013, something like that, big conference.
I spent a whole afternoon with one of the best-trained, charismatic, wonderful male
guides, as experienced as the women.
And we spent an afternoon together.
I got his life story.
And it's like I can, the texture is different.
He doesn't have that same quality of intuition
and working with these unseen energies that
the women are so expressive about.
I mean, they say such interesting things that are hard to define.
And in the three or four hours I spent with
this guy, listening to him, he didn't go into
those really subtle realms.
So one example I talk about is this one woman
guide said, when she feels the client needs
more space in what she's doing in her ceremony,
she needs to have a little more space, she's
getting boxed in or too narrow.
She said, I'll take a big expansive breath, and that will help my client.
So I'm taking notes, I'm writing this all down, because I didn't record.
It's too delicate an illegal situation, I took notes instead of recording.
And I'm transcribing my notes, and I think, what does this mean?
I intuitively understand that the guide that
the woman creates, the woman elder creates
a spaciousness inside herself.
And somehow the client under the blanket, journeying, benefits from that in her own
inner spaciousness.
That spaciousness travels or is communicated or merges with the client.
That's the kind of inner outer permeation that the men don't talk about in quite the
same way.
And that's specifically what I was interested in.
As a parapsychologist, I might say, oh, they're telepathic.
But I don't think using a word like that begins to get at what's really going on.
Right, because it's also so somatic.
It's so embodied.
And the breath itself, you know, is one of
those things that travels from the inner world
to the outer world.
And so there's already an exchange of inner and outer with the breath.
This is what Jung began to call synchronicity,
when a client was talking about, what was
it, a beetle?
And then a beetle flew in the window of the therapy room, that something changes from
within and then something changes, is reflected in the outer material world.
And so I think that's part of what this woman
was describing, that she creates more space
inside herself, and that gives her client more space in the journey.
I just think it's a wonderful statement.
And not that I understand it completely, because there's mystery involved in this.
When you compare these women to the ancient
priestesses in the Eleusinian mysteries, who,
according to some scholars, have guided
people through a psychedelic experience also.
Yes, and it was preparation for death, and they were also sworn to secrecy.
So there's some real parallels.
And when we think about the entheogens entering
into the modern world, we don't have a category
for these women underground elders.
We don't have a role, you know, we're mostly
looking at the psychedelic medicines in terms
of a medical setting, that we're collecting data, we're doing studies, we want it to be
cost-effective, and we're looking at symptom reduction.
We'd like to understand how it works, so we're
exploring mystical experience in some, you
know, the neurological studies, how does this work?
But the outcome measures are symptom reduction.
The women work in very different ways.
The way they hold and understand their work and
the journeys is a much bigger way of holding it.
And it's far more sacred.
I mean, the eldest of the elders, she says,
even if these medicines become legal, I will
continue to work underground.
So it's this real sense of that's where the sacred world is.
You've described one experience with a woman
who was a good friend of yours who isn't part
of the 15 women you studied, but was also, as I
understand it, maybe equivalently experienced.
You were talking to her about how in some sessions for people it's natural to come up
with family issues, especially issues around parents and childhood.
This friend got right in your face and told you very definitively, we have no interest
whatsoever in family issues.
Well, this was a mistake I made from the very beginning.
I thought these women were psychedelic therapists, and they're not.
Not at all.
They're interested in a transformation process
that goes way beyond what psychotherapists
think of having a better life, doing better in
your relationships, managing yourself better.
One woman says, you develop your intentions for yourself and for humanity.
I mean, look at that vision this woman holds,
that you're journeying, yes, for yourself
and for humanity, it goes way beyond just you.
Yes, this friend of mine, what was really
interesting to me about it is this was early
on as I was interviewing people.
She's shamanically trained with a Peruvian shaman, but she didn't work underground.
That's the only reason I could use her name.
She has many books.
Her name is Connie Grouts.
I was certain she yelled at me, that she came
right in my face like inches away from my
nose and screamed at the top of her lungs.
And I backed off and I quieted down and I stopped
asking family of origin therapy questions.
And hours later, I asked a friend of mine who had been part of the conversation.
I said to her, Connie had left, I said to my friend, I said, did Connie yell at me?
Did she scream at me?
And my friend said, no.
And she looked at me as if I was crazy.
Why do you ask?
I said, because that's how I hold that memory.
I still hold it that way.
And my understanding is she did a shamanic intervention.
She shocked me out of my standard therapy questions and perspective.
And that is when I really shifted and realized
this is what William James would call a conversion
experience that there's a real shift in the architecture of the psyche.
It's not just a resolution to, well, now I'm no longer angry at my mother.
It's a real shift in how I identify who I am and how I am in the world.
And this happens in other situations as well as psychedelic journeys.
And the most predictable ones are spontaneous
awakening experiences and near death experiences.
People do have these spiritual awakenings where there's a real shift in who they are
and their priorities in life and people change their lives.
And there was a study done on what was called quantum change.
And there's a paperback book about it done by some psychologists.
And what was so interesting, they just
advertised for spontaneous spiritual experiences,
nothing to do with drugs.
And the people they interviewed, they followed them up 10 years later,
which is very hard to do in data collection.
10 years later, they found most of the cohort, most of the group.
And the way that people had changed their values
and their priorities in life remained stable.
So they were much more community oriented, much
more empathic, interested in relationships,
how they could contribute to the world.
They were more likely to be working in terms of
climate change and protecting the environment.
They really shifted their values and how they spent their lives.
And this is what the women look for when they're working with someone.
They look for that kind of transformation.
So in effect, these special people are
functioning as priests or priestesses or shamans.
And but without any title, without any official authority of any sort behind them,
based on really something, well, a combination
of the training that they had and a calling,
a deep calling.
A deep calling.
Yeah, yeah.
And I was called to graduate school.
Well, it's a wonderful thing to have a calling because many people don't have one.
It served me well, but it's different.
It's very different.
I went to graduate school.
I was a graduate student for 10 years.
And in graduate school, it's really more about indoctrination than education.
In a way, you get indoctrinated into the Western materialistic model, the paradigm
that becomes primary.
And I remember I had a mentor, Arthur M. Young,
who was a brilliant inventor and a cosmologist
and an astrologer.
And after I graduated, I went to visit him and he picked up his ephemeris and said,
well, how long were you working on your dissertation?
That was six of the 10 years.
And he said, well, it's going to take you
another six years to undo all the damage the
university has done to you.
And looking back, I can say he was correct.
He was correct.
Yes.
But how wonderful that he could tell you that.
Yeah.
But these women, in a way, they bypassed that indoctrination.
In a way, it's almost as if they are indoctrinated differently.
Yes, they are.
One woman apprenticed with a Native American.
This kind of spiritual apprenticeship is like
an adoption and she calls him grandfather.
And she was adopted into that tribe.
So, this is a different kind of training.
And she's the one who told me she did a vision quest on a mountain.
And I think it was three days and nights, no food.
No food.
All right.
People do manage that.
I wouldn't like it, but no water.
Now, that's different.
That does something very different to the body and the consciousness.
And she did a number of those vision quests.
As I recall, you wrote about how she woke up one night sleeping alone without a tent
under the sky and felt a heavy presence,
something pushing on her and opened her eyes.
And it was a jaguar.
That was a different woman.
You see, they have some of the same capacities for these experiences.
Yes.
Yeah.
I don't know why I think a tent would
protect me from a mountain lion and a jaguar.
But anyway, yeah.
And what was interesting about that story, she didn't move.
I mean, the jaguar was on her.
And it scratched from her leg, from her hip to her knee.
And what's interesting is she spent the next couple of days in communion,
talking with that jaguar.
So you see how she took the animal from the material world into her inner world
and worked with that spirit animal.
And she felt part of what she learned was about
fear because her nature is not to be afraid.
But she did learn about fear to see this animal on top of her.
She did learn about fear this way.
And she felt this was something she had to learn about to work with people who
most people do have fear when getting ready for a journey.
And so it was this kind of initiation for her.
And of course, being around any wild animal is going to
activate very instinctive fear mechanisms, I would think.
Yeah, just the thought of it is enough to scare me.
This is why I'm not part of this group.
Well, you described a very interesting episode
in your own process when you heard this story.
And it's because she described, if I remember correctly,
being in the United States in the mountains in northern Idaho,
where you know there aren't any jaguars.
It's very confusing.
But here she's telling me this incredible energetic spiritual story.
And as she's telling it, she's reliving it.
I mean, this kind of story has energy that lasts a whole lifetime.
So the event happened 30 some years ago.
But it felt extremely real and present.
I mean, the energy continues.
And I made a therapeutic error.
So she's telling me this incredible shamanic story.
And I correct her and say, well, it probably wasn't a jaguar.
They're not they don't travel that far north,
as if I know anything about wild animals.
I don't know anything.
And then I realized, you know, this was a mistake.
And I stopped myself.
You know, it was like a no at all statement when I really didn't know anything.
And I kind of got back on the energetic track with her.
And and continued with her experience.
And we both entered into this experience, which I have to give myself credit for.
I'm actually good at this.
I'm good at entering into this experience with her.
But there's no way I'd be on a mountain at night in or out of a tent.
But anyway, I then had to Google, you know, the mountain lion, a puma, a jaguar.
What's their territory?
How do you differentiate them?
And frankly, it's very confusing.
It's hard to differentiate these large cats,
but they are at the top of the predator.
And, you know, they're very frightening.
Even after she told me this experience, which
frankly, I don't think she had repeated to
anybody.
I think this is something she I mean, who do you tell something like this to?
And so, you know, once I corrected myself and got back on track with her, you know,
it opened this story and this energy to continue to work on her.
It was still alive in her.
But to be able to share it with me opened it up again.
And then she was able to connect it with other
things in her life that happened decades later,
but had to do with a jaguar and, you know, a little statue of a jaguar, carving of a
jaguar.
So, it became even more meaningful as this spirit animal unfolded in her life.
Well, it strikes me that this story that you've
told so well is an example of the difference
between a masculine and a feminine approach to things.
She's speaking to you at the energetic level and the masculine line wants to say,
is this true or not?
She had no doubts.
She never, she didn't go there.
Yeah.
And, you know, once I got my ego in check that I can go with her and I had no doubts
about this story.
And so, participating with these women,
hearing these kinds of stories, it changed me.
You know, I benefited.
I'm different than I was, you know, four
years ago when I started this, five years ago.
I really became more permeable myself and more open.
I'm just as afraid as ever.
My fear did not reduce.
But I feel like I'm more open to the spirit world, to the energetic world, the sense of
things live in the inner world and the outer
world and they move back and forth between
each other.
You know, when it's appropriate, I try and
always include, I'm in therapy with a Jungian
analyst that, you know, after all these years
of being in therapy, doing therapy, I'm still
in therapy.
And I was reporting a dream and she said, well, and there's like a masculine energy
in the dream.
And she said, well, look for that energy to show up in your life.
So again, you hear this kind of Jungian understanding
of that synchronicity between the inner world
and the outer world.
And this is not the kind of psychology or therapy that's taught in graduate schools.
This is more esoteric and it's got a mystical, magical quality to it.
But this inner outer is so interesting in the psyche.
And of course, that's what's happening in a journey.
You talk about how when you work with these women, sometimes you would have a day-long
conversation.
It could last six hours or so, going into the details of all the work they do.
And it affected you to the extent you felt like you were having a contact high.
Absolutely.
Absolutely.
I can tell you the story.
I spent, it was 12 hours, nine in the morning
to nine at night, with two Native American
women.
And so, they work with prayer and songs and peyote.
And, you know, we spent most of the time in the dining room at the dining room table.
I'm making notes.
We're talking.
We break for lunch.
We go out to dinner later.
Somebody else joins us.
I mean, it's a whole day.
We're back in the house.
It's nine o'clock at night.
And they, you know, we're women.
And they say, do you want to use the bathroom before you leave?
Because I have an hour's drive.
And I answer, I don't know.
And they got it immediately.
And so, they sort of took charge.
And they said, well, go to the bathroom.
So, I just obeyed them.
I went to the bathroom.
I did need to pee.
I come back out.
I'm still kind of wifty.
And they say, you know, come this way.
And we walked through the dining room where we had spent all day.
And they open a door I hadn't noticed.
And it's a door that leads into their ceremonial room.
So, as a researcher, I sat all day taking notes.
And I missed, I was never invited into the ceremonial room.
I missed the presence of the door.
I missed it.
So, we go into the room.
And they have all their shamanic objects and
feathers and stones and different things.
And they do a clearing on me for like 30 minutes.
And they're, you know, they're whistling.
And they're ruffling feathers around my energy field.
And I got myself together.
And I drove home.
And I thought, well, you know, this is, there's so much in this story that, yes,
it's a contact high, but that I was shifting worlds without knowing it.
And also that I could have easily missed, I could have really missed
so much in that ceremonial room.
And so, I just felt very, very lucky that I
serendipitously, you know, sort of got ungrounded.
And that they helped me in that way.
And they opened up this other world that I didn't know about.
Well, in shamanic practice, as I understand it, which is probably pretty minimal, the
idea is that the shaman is able to travel to
the upper worlds and the lower worlds at ease.
They're just as comfortable in these mystical
worlds as they are here on the physical plane.
But I gather that not all of the women you interviewed work in a shamanic mode.
No, they don't all.
And they don't, only one or two of them have mentorships with indigenous shaman.
So, the others are trained in other ways.
Well, there's a Native American medicine man, which is a little different.
But some of them trained with, you do know the book, The Secret Chief, about Leo Zeff.
He was one of the first people in the San Francisco Bay Area, you're nodding,
you were there at the time, you know, in the late 60s, early 60s, he was working.
He came out of retirement when he discovered
these entheogens and went back into practice
working with them.
He thought they were so powerful.
And that's the calling, the recognition that
these medicines are so powerful and have such
potential for healing, that people are willing to
take the risk to come out and work underground.
And so, he trained a number of the people because they're elders and they worked with
some of the historical figures.
And others of them worked with Stan Grof and
Ralph Metzner, people that have written lots
of books and we recognize the names.
And so, they have lots of different sources
for their apprenticeships and their own work
on themselves.
Did you find a common thread that ran through all 15?
Well, besides their fearlessness, I would say their commitment to their own healing.
So, yes, it was, they worked on themselves intensively for years before they began to
work on others.
And they continue to work on themselves with the entheogens.
And that's a whole different, it's a life with
psychedelics and that the healing continues.
And one of the women used the phrase, an
experience she had continues to work on her.
There's this sense of a simmering pot that things keep moving inside.
And it's not just about the ceremony, but it's about the process.
And I found the information that Albert Hoffman,
who synthesized LSD-25, he lived to an old
age, I think it was 102.
When he was 97, he did an LSD trip.
So, you get a sense of this whole lifetime of working with medicines, shifting worlds
and realities, and the sense of permeability with other worlds.
You know, I interviewed Houston Smith's widow.
Kendra.
Kendra.
I don't know if you know her.
She's turning 100 this summer.
And I thought the story was of such historical significance.
And it was also another story of a woman not having a voice in the culture.
I mean, she was born a few years after women got the vote.
So, you know, she didn't have the opportunities that women have now.
But she and Houston, well, here's how it went.
All this Huxley in California.
I might be missing something here.
But somehow, I think it was Huxley was at MIT where Houston was teaching.
And Huxley knew there was something happening at Harvard.
There was a young psychologist at Harvard.
That young psychologist was Timothy Leary.
So he sent Houston, and Houston took his wife
to meet Timothy Leary and do an LSD trip in
Leary's home on the third floor of his old house in Newton, Massachusetts.
So Kendra took two or three times the dose that Houston took.
And this was Houston's first experience.
I mean, he'd written about the perennial
philosophy and mysticism and the core of all
the world religions.
But this was his first direct experience of union, of a mystical experience.
Kendra took two or three times the dose that Houston took.
And she had her own experience.
And we sat and talked for an hour or two.
And then I just asked her, Kendra, has
anybody else ever interviewed you about this?
This is a historic experience.
And she said, no, nobody ever asked.
Nobody seemed interested.
This is a statement from a woman from that generation.
And, you know, we hope things are better now.
Well, forgive me if I seem presumptuous, Rachel, but I'm under the impression that
this story you've just told exemplifies a reality that all women seem to face,
that they are subordinate, they're second-class citizens at some level.
I think the concept that's come up in the Black Studies program of intersectionality,
how all, you know, being a woman, if you combine that with being black or brown,
they intersect.
It makes you even worse that there's this whole issue of social status.
And even women of high social status, and Kendra, I suppose, would be such a woman,
the daughter of a philosopher, the wife of a famous professor, and so on, is still...
And a PhD in her own right.
Yeah.
Women have, I mean, it talks about in the Bible how women are forced because of
Eve's sin to give birth and to experience pain.
But it's like there's an extra wound you carry just being born female.
You know, I don't think people address it so directly, but I've seen it over and over
and over again.
I wonder, am I being presumptuous to say that?
No, I think you're exactly right.
And I think this is a generational thing for me.
I feel a little hesitant to state this on my
own, that I'll get some backlash of some sort.
And I actually agree with everything you've said.
And it continues.
You know, one of the women who testified in this current trial against Trump, that she
had her own unfortunate encounter with him,
where he was abusive and crossed boundaries.
She's walking out of the courthouse, and she says, it's still a man's world.
This was just a few days ago.
This was on the news.
And that's her statement.
This is how difficult it is for women to speak up and to have their voices heard.
At the same time, I'm under the impression that being wounded in that way can also be
a strength.
It's not always a strength, but it can become a strength.
And I imagine these healers or spiritual guides
that you've interviewed turned it into a strength.
I think it helped to make them more sensitive.
I think they were, you know, I asked them about
their childhoods and their early spiritual
experiences, just spontaneous as children.
And they had very interesting dreams and experiences.
They were already shifting realities.
So they were called to this work because they were often more sensitive.
And so they were different in a few different ways.
And what was interesting to me is many of them did not have children.
Of course, some did, but more than half did not.
So they were able to dedicate their lives to
this process of their own work on themselves
and their own explorations.
So that's another commonality that they have.
And it's a different sort of a life as a woman.
And then again, it speaks to the priestess quality.
You write very briefly in your book about, I
would call her the grandmother of psychedelics,
Mexican shamanist Maria Sabina, after whom, I'm stumbling over words, but what I mean
to say is really the title of your book is a tribute to her.
Yes, one of the songs that she would sing in ceremony was, she's a Mexican corandera
working with psilocybin, the little saints, the mushrooms.
She would sing, I am a woman who swims in the sacred.
And that's as good a description of these women as anything.
They are living in a world that's qualitatively different.
I think you could trace an important landmark
in the modern evolution of entheogens in Western
culture to, I guess it was Gordon Wasson and
accompanied by a few people, Stanley Kripner,
I think was one.
I've interviewed him about it.
Went to Mexico to experience psilocybin with Maria Sabina.
Yes, and in this story, I want to point out
that Gordon Wasson's wife was the mycologist.
She knew about mushrooms far more than he did.
And she often not even mentioned.
Another example of the way women are put in the back seat.
Yeah, and what happened was once this became
known, there was a Life magazine article about
the ceremonies with psilocybin, with magic mushrooms.
A lot of Westerners went down to this little
village and Maria Sabina had to move to get
away from them.
And she said, you know, with all, it was beatniks and hippies.
And she said, you know, the mushrooms are no longer working.
And so she was just inundated.
And this speaks to the problem that we have now.
As a culture, how do we work with these mystical medicines?
And we don't have a clear way to do it.
I mean, so far, we've got a medical approach to them.
We have a corporate approach, people wanting
to make money, but we don't really have a
sacred way in the culture.
And the sacred approach is in the underground.
And this is a challenge for us with this psychedelic renaissance.
How do we hold these entheogens in the biggest,
most sacred, most spiritual kind of way?
And in that sense, these women you interviewed are at the forefront.
Yes, yes, that's correct.
And they don't have a voice, exactly.
And I've been very disappointed that the research teams have not sought them out.
Because they certainly don't want to go public, public.
But I know a good number of them would be happy to meet with the research team.
And they have not really sought them out.
There is one woman who is somehow, because of who she is, is working with a study team
and helping to train people.
And she's been able to cross that divide.
That's one.
Well, there's been an interest in what's called transpersonal psychology, which is
the branch of almost mainstream psychology
that does study the sacred, the mystical, the
psychic, and the intuitive side of life.
That would be a place where you could merge,
I suppose, the sacred side with the empirical,
therapeutic aspects of psychedelics.
They're writing about the critical importance of a mystical experience.
It's still held in terms of symptom reduction.
And there's sort of like this, well, is it the molecule?
What makes the difference?
Is it the chemical?
Is it the molecule?
Is it material, in other words?
Or is it something else that's happening?
And we don't really know.
And I think there's a chemist at UC Davis who's working on developing
a psychedelic that doesn't take so long, that
doesn't involve the psychedelic experience,
but changes the brain in a similar way.
And is that going to work?
I mean, it's sort of like years, I think I wrote about this in the ayahuasca book.
There was a study that was planned using shaman.
And in order to get a standardized dose of ayahuasca, they freeze dried it,
which is what they've been doing in Spain when they do the research.
And when they showed it to the shaman, the shaman said,
we're not going to do a ceremony with that.
There's no spirit in those capsules.
You've lost the plant.
So we don't really know how to relate to things that we can't measure.
And we can't control in a study.
And we just don't know how to bring that into our culture and transform our culture
so that we can relate to those mystical aspects even more.
So maybe there's a real benefit to the fact that
there is an underground that isn't constrained
by the requirements of Western intellectual authority.
Yes.
And I think that's why the eldest of the elders
says she would continue to work underground.
I think it preserves it.
And there was a recent article in the New York Times where they found
in what they called a burial cave on an island off the coast of Spain.
And they found remnants of bodies and they analyzed the hair.
And it had evidence of psychotropic plants in the hair that had been used
because they could tell from where it is in the hair,
how long those plants had been used by that person.
And it's been used for over a year.
This is from 3,000 years ago, by the way, these remnants of bodies.
3,000 years ago in a burial cave.
So again, you get this sense of underground and preparation for death and dying.
And that the medicines here was a way that that culture, 3,000 years ago,
had a way, a ritualistic way of using psychotropic
plants to prepare for death and dying.
You know, we're not quite there yet.
Well, I know Aldous Huxley famously took, I think it was mescaline as he was dying.
I think it was a shot of LSD.
LSD?
Yeah, I think Laura Huxley gave him intramuscular LSD.
I know of other examples.
In fact, we did an interview about a very well-known person in the Bay Area.
I bet you knew Jean Millet.
No.
Well, Jean Millet was a researcher and a shaman and married at one time to Ala Raka,
the tabla player, a very important person in the psychedelic movement early on.
She died about two, three years ago and took LSD as she was dying.
It would be consistent, I suppose, with the
original insight of Leary, Alpert and Metzner
when they wrote the psychedelic experience based on the Tibetan Book of the Dead.
Exactly, exactly.
Yeah, so we have little glimmers of these sacred ways of using the entheogens.
There's been very little follow-up along those
lines in the literature that I'm aware of.
No, it's existing underground.
It's very quiet.
Of course, I know many of the psychologists on the research teams.
There's nothing crazy happening like there was
in the 60s with Leary and the drugs getting out
of the lab and people are using these entheogens
in the way of living with these medicines
throughout a lifespan, with getting experience
with them, exploring, doing their own healing.
They're not just doing symptom reduction on themselves.
They're using the medicines in the way these
underground women use them in their own healing,
the way I do.
It was in talking with Kendra, she just sort of dreamily said,
oh, I'd love to do another journey.
You know, it's interesting.
You did spend almost a full chapter in your book writing about one man.
I think his name was Al Hubbard, who was very
instrumental in the late 50s, early 60s and maybe
into the 70s and sort of spreading the gospel of LSD.
He became, even though in some ways I think you
describe him as, well, almost a fraud in the
sense that he had a PhD that he got purchased from some diploma mill.
But he seemed to function as an authentic spiritual guide.
Absolutely.
You know, when we talk about set and setting, he deserves the initial credit.
And I feel very strongly we should really recognize him more.
Yes, he was a rascal and a scoundrel.
I think he worked for the government in MKUltra.
I mean, nobody knew the whole truth about this man.
But he had a spiritual experience as a child.
And he felt he had a relationship with the Virgin Mary his whole life.
And that that relationship led him to these medicines and informed him that it was a
spiritual experience he was working with, that
this was a spiritual conversion experience.
So yes, they helped alcoholics.
This is in the 50s.
The research was used a lot with alcoholics.
Yes, they could help alcoholics.
But it was because it was a spiritual experience.
And so he's the one who framed the journey with music and earphones and eye shades.
So it would become an internal experience.
People would be turned inward.
And then toward the end, and he would have religious objects in the room and artwork
to kind of inspire religious feelings.
And he really deserves the credit.
I think Leary presented a paper in the early 60s on set and setting.
So he often gets the professional credit for that.
But it really came from Al Hubbard.
And it came from his early childhood experience.
And this led me to asking the women about their early experiences.
And I've had early spiritual experience as a child.
But the women, they traveled in their experiences.
I would sometimes sort of receive or recognize that I was shifting in some way.
But some of the women reported dreams that were just...
I've listened to people's dreams for 40 years.
I'm still listening to people's dreams.
And these dreams are like over the top, that
they would meet entities from other worlds.
I mean, they really, before they used any medicines of any kind,
they could travel in their dreams and sometimes
in just hypnagogic states, they could travel.
So that's part of what I mean that they were very open to other worlds.
And I think this guy, Al Hubbard, as crazy as he was,
crazy as he was, I think he had this alive inspiration from the Virgin Mary
that really guided him in his commitment to...
I mean, he's called the Johnny Appleseed of LSD.
And his commitment to wanting the world to
change as a result of these mystical experiences.
Now, I have to add, he would do this,
I think it was called an advanced training.
And he would take people out to the Mojave Desert.
The desert is a classic spiritual landscape,
the desert fathers, the Middle East, the desert.
And so they would trip out on the desert.
And then after a day of recovery, he would take his little group to Las Vegas,
assuming they would have better luck gambling.
But no, they didn't.
So that didn't work.
So he stopped that.
But that was the experiment.
So you see, there were two sides to this man.
He was a very complex character.
There were two sides to him.
Do you think he had an influence in any way on the women you've interviewed?
I think he influenced everybody.
I think he influenced, you know, I think there
is a lineage of Al Hubbard, Myron Stolaroff,
Leo Zeff, that then went to a few of the elders who I interviewed.
But this is a little esoteric.
People may not even know these names anymore.
But when I mentioned the book, the best way
to click into this is the Secret Chief book.
And that was Myron Stolaroff's book about Leo Zeff.
And he said, you know, this was one of the
characteristics of what would make a good guide.
And the description of Leo Zeff was just, I don't have this exact quote,
but he had an unusually compassionate heart.
I mean, this is a wonderful description of
someone who's spent his whole life as a therapist,
mind you.
But that this was a capacity that he had that
was helpful in being present for people during
journeys.
So I think there is a lineage here that's now historical.
And I have to say, I'm writing this book interviewing women.
I spent a good six months on Al Hubbard,
trying to find everything I could about him.
And there's a lot of mystery about him because he kept a lot of secrets.
When it comes to having these early childhood
spiritual experiences of such a profound nature
and many spontaneous shamanic or psychic experiences as a child,
there's quite a bit of literature that suggests
that these kinds of experiences are correlated
with early childhood trauma.
I get the feeling that children who are traumatized go inward.
They turn inside or they even find imaginary
worlds where they can be protected and safe.
And that opens them up to these psychic worlds.
Did you find that in the women you interviewed
that they'd had more than the average amount
of childhood trauma?
No, I didn't.
But Donald Kaushik writes about that.
And because children during a trauma event will leave their bodies and that opens up,
that sort of opens up that availability and accessibility to another world.
As a matter of fact, I was working with a
client and he talked about he had been sexually
abused as a child.
And he talked about this experience of leaving his body.
And I found that movie with Jodie Foster where she travels.
She's an astronaut who travels and shifts realities and time zones and she meets her
father.
And the section of the movie where she's traveling through dimensions, I played that
for this client.
And he said, that's exactly what I did.
He recognized it immediately.
So that is one way people enter into other worlds.
But I didn't find that with these women, especially.
They just had an openness and a willingness and an engagement in these.
If they would meet an entity, they would talk, they would have a conversation as a
child.
No academic understanding of this, just the natural thing to do.
And I just found it very unusual.
And I included, there is a questionnaire that
looks at early childhood spiritual experiences
that people can look at these 20 items and say, oh yeah, I had that.
Or no, I didn't have that.
And it kind of brings up these memories.
And a number of the people who are interested
in this world or working with the medicines,
even professionally, the researchers, they had childhood experiences that were sort of
like little stepping stones that they kind of followed throughout their life.
I mean, this is how I got to Esalen at 21.
I graduated from college and I went right into the Esalen Residential Program because
I had been following these experiences.
Where could I find people who were talking about this?
And that led me to Esalen.
So I was the youngest person there.
People were working on loosening up their defenses.
I didn't have enough defenses.
So, but it's almost like little clues in life to find your way there.
And these women had that.
And this is something I do share with them.
But they reported extraordinary experiences.
Well, Rachel Harris, you have made a sincere
and authentic and profound contribution to
the emerging world of psychedelic research
and therapy by introducing the voices of women
who otherwise would be silent, would remain unheard.
So, I really have to compliment you on the service that you're performing for a very
large and growing community that would, but for your work, be unaware of this.
I just want to point out, I dedicate the book to the women I interviewed.
It's their story.
It's a shame that, I think for the most part, they will remain unnamed.
Yes.
Well, Rachel Harris, thank you so much for being with me.
This was a very heartfelt, and I keep using the word profound, interview.
I think it is.
It's a delight to be with you again.
Thank you, Jeff.
I so appreciate the time.
For those of you watching or listening, thank you for being with us.
The inaugural issue of the New Thinking Allowed
magazine was just released on March 1st.
You can download a free PDF copy from the New Thinking Allowed Foundation website.
